findings.title: Lack of contract existence check on delegatecall may lead to unexpected behavior
findings.description: The `Ladle` contract uses the `delegatecall` proxy pattern without performing a contract existence check prior to executing a `delegatecall`, which may lead to failed executions if the implementation contract is incorrectly set or self-destructed.

findings.title: Use of delegatecall in a payable function inside a loop
findings.description: The Ladle contract uses the delegatecall proxy pattern (which takes user-provided call data) in a payable function within a loop.

findings.title: Lack of two-step process for critical operations
findings.description: The protocol's functions emit events for critical operations but lack a two-step process.

findings.title: Risks associated with use of ABIEncoderV2
findings.description: The contracts use Solidity's `ABIEncoderV2`, which is enabled by default in Solidity version 0.8 and has caused numerous issues in the past.

findings.title: Project dependencies contain vulnerabilities
findings.description: The project's dependencies have known vulnerabilities which can lead to arbitrary code execution, regular expression denial of service, and arbitrary file creation/overwrite.

findings.title: Witch's buy and payAll functions allow users to buy collateral from vaults not undergoing auctions
findings.description: The Witch contract's buy and payAll functions do not check for active auctions on vaults, allowing users to buy collateral at below-market prices and creating an arbitrage opportunity.

findings.title: Solidity compiler optimizations can be problematic
findings.description: High-severity security issues due to optimization bugs have occurred in the past and may occur in the future, causing security vulnerabilities in smart contracts.

findings.title: Risks associated with EIP-2612
findings.description: The use of EIP-2612 increases the risk of `permit` function front-running as well as phishing attacks.

findings.title: Failure to use the batched transaction follow may enable theft through front-running
findings.description: When users deviate from the batched transaction flow, they may lose their funds through front-running, for example, an attacker could front-run the `startPool()` function to steal the initial mint of strategy tokens.

findings.title: Strategy contract’s balance-tracking system could facilitate theft
findings.description: The `Strategy` contract functions use the contract’s balance to determine how many liquidity or base tokens to provide to a user minting or burning tokens.

findings.title: Insufficient protection of sensitive keys
findings.description: Sensitive keys are not properly protected.

findings.title: Lack of limits on the total amount of collateral sold at auction
findings.description: The protocol does not have global and type-specific limits on the amount of collateral that can be auctioned off at the same time, which may lead to total liquidation caused by bugs or attacks.

findings.title: Lack of incentives for calls to Witch.auction
findings.description: The Yield Protocol system does not provide users with a direct incentive to call `Witch.auction`, which may lead to delayed auctions and greater losses.

findings.title: Contracts used as dependencies do not track upstream changes
findings.description: The master branch of one repository of the protocol is not compatible with the master branch of another, leading to problems when a new version of the protocol is deployed.

findings.title: Cauldron’s give and tweak functions lack vault existence checks
findings.description: The Cauldron's give and tweak functions do not check if a vault exists before operating on it, which can lead to unintended consequences for the protocol.
